pages.text: Laidleria's fossil was found in sediments dated to some time within the early to mid-Triassic period, coming from modern day South Africa. It was a fairly small temnospondyl amphibian, growing to somewhere in the region of 30-40cm in length, with a very flat body and skull, and with sprawling legs. The single fossil known has been studied since 1957 and presented researchers with some difficulty in interpreting,

partly due to the position it was fossilised in and partly to less than perfect preservation of some parts. The latest major work on it dates from 1998. It possessed a light covering of armour-like scutes on its back. Its exact taxonomic positioning is still uncertain.
